element_texts.text: Completed

about 8.30 & not a single one of our wagons had yet succeeded in crossing - I was satisfied that some of them would not get over before 12 m.  Half a mile further on was a crossing equally bad & a mile on still another.  I felt that the safe crossing of the three could not be effected before 1 or 2 pm - so I put
Completed

of last night - The wagons commenced to arrive by 3 pm & by 5 all mine were in the supply train did not all arrive until about dark - The difficulties are manifold only two weeks ago we went over this same ground 20 miles a day - Then our mules were comparatively fresh & strong.  There was
Completed

foothold for them - This has been a day of terrible hardship & trial for all of us - Men & animals - 
It cleared off about noon.  the sun came out & the wind shifted to the south - but all to no good purpose.  The thm'r has been between 2º & -2º all day -  It has been bitter in the extreme
Completed

Genl C. talks of attempting a short cut from some point on this stream to Wind Creek - His object is to make a road across there.  It will be useful hereafter.  I have talked against this plan as it is no weather in which to make experiments & he might get the Comd involved in the bad lands & lose many men -
Completed

Belle Fourch  
Decr 24, 76 -
Reveille at 6:30 - The mules were herded last night that is the teamsters turned them loose & they went where they pleased - consequently when my wagons were loaded there was no team to pull them.  However the teamsters fussed around & so got those mules together
Completed

camped in the same place a deep ravine & the Comd is in its old place - The day has been terrific  My Ther'r only indicates -17º. At 7 am this morning the mercury was in the bulb, several degrees below 17° & I am of opinion that during the night the temperature was well nigh -30 - I am led to this conclusion by the fact that the coldest time of the
Completed

soon after getting in camp my striker - Kistler - came running up with my cap which he said he had found in my bed - Now as I went through each seperate item of that bed twice since that cap was lost without finding it - I am constrained to suspect that some one gobbled that cap but brought it back when he found I made such a fuss about its loss
Completed

the whole day has not been higher than -10º - Fortunately there has been very little wind - one can stand still cold but I have never worked harder than I did today in keeping my nose & fingers from freezing.  I, this am, put on my buckskins & have not been uncomfortable except my face & my hands - but I really feared I would freeze some part of me
Completed

Genl C's tent having no light, I went into Bowshy's where I found Randall, just in from his extraordinary trip in search of the Crows  He brought in about 80 too late to be of service & they can only go back - He is looking well considering the hardships he has gone through - after a chat with him I went to the Genls tent & soon after Mackenzie &
Completed

However I wont growl I have got the cap & my nose is pretty safe in the future - While I was at dinner I got a message from Genl Crook saying he would like to see me in half an hour - but in such terms as led me to believe the request social instead of official - I went of course but
Completed

Several telegrams to Genl C.  We meet a train tomorro with rations & forage - another waits us at Wind Creek - We had a jolly evening, drinking & telling stories, but alas! the pitcher was not the widows conise? & when the Genl went out to replenish he found that there was no more - The staff had gobbled all - The Staff is a nuisance & ought to be abolished of course with nothing to
Completed

Townsend came in - all by invitation - after a little while the "Swarry" was brought in consisting of a [crossed out: most]  pitcher of most excellent brandy punch hot - We all did ample justice to it & the occasion drinking to the occasion & to our absent loved ones - & happy meetings with them -  Randal brought me a letter from Goodall &
Completed

enough for Hdqr & to spare - I went up there.  He was hard at work patching Hdqr tents  He looked cold & thirsty - I invited him to come to my tent & get a drink & he at once accepted - we went casually by his wood pile I told him I was out of wood & that I would like a log - In the openness of his heart he told me to send up a man & he would give me one - I did so. you bet - & have a fire
Completed

drink we soon broke up - I came home to find all my people in bed - & no fire in my tent  I soon had one however - for I had plenty of wood - When I got into camp I found that my Sergt had deceived me saying we had plenty of wood, when we had not & I was in the happy condition No wood & no chance t get any without genius - Egan had lots of wood -
Completed

Near Grand Spring   Decm 25, 1876
Was waked up about 3 am by the cold & though I had so much covering that it was cumbersome from its weight I could not get warm - Tried all manner of ways & finally was rejoiced to hear reveille - Waited for some time for my man to come
Completed

A drink is worth a log of wood any day - 
The weather has moderated greatly, but it is still far below zero - There is however no wind & we have every prospect of a good day tomorrow - I hope so most cordially - No water no grass no wood tonight - & yet  it is Xmas Eve - How different for some people -
Only 7 miles today -
Completed

these to my man - He is however a German - one of the most incapable of that incapable nation - & with all my previous instructions - the daily making of fire for near two months - & the pine splinters, he utterly failed & after seeing him bungle unsuccessfully for full 20 minutes I was at last obliged to git up in my night clothes & make the fire myself
Completed

& make my fire & getting impatient looked out to find it still dark night - It was Mackenzies reveille I had heard & I had to wait & shiver for an hour & a half until my reveille should bring my man - at last both came - I had last night in anticipation of the terrible cold cut a lot of small shavings to kindle the fire & showed
Completed

Breakfast was frozen stiff before it could be set on the table - Fortunately we got hot coffee - When all the wagons were loaded it was found that the teamsters had not reported & when they at last came to their teams many mules were absent & had to be hunted up - It was at least 10 oclock am before the teams were ready to start - I do not understand how so usually astute a man as Genl
Completed

My preparations were fortunately so complete that it took me not three minutes or I must have frozen -  It was intensely terrifically cold - at 7 am the thermometer was frozen - the mercury gathered? the Doctor thaws it out but in half an hour afterwards it was frozen again hard - It must have been 50º below zero - Everything & everybody was frozen up -
Completed

reported & got my camp ground.  The wagons commenced to get in by 4 but all were not in until between 7 & 8 pm -  Men & wagons kept standing waiting, without food for more than 14 hours - all to enable some teamsters - princes in disguise - to sleep a little longer in the morning - I ventilated my opinion on such arrangements very openly.  The Genl listened only
Completed

Crook can be so utterly obtuse as to the value & capacity of his QrMrc  The whole com'd delayed at least 3 hours in the morning because a few of his teamsters chose to sleep a little longer - & yet he appears to think it all right -
I started about 9 am - leaving my com'd to follow - The road is generally good but there are two terribly bad places.  I got into camp about 2 pm
Completed

is afraid of them - They know it & do just as they please - Mackenzie tried to mollify me tonight by saying that Fury was doing his best & was really a very good specimen of a regular Qr Ms.  I agreed with him entirely  I do think Fury a willing energetic hard working man & one of the best regular qrmrs I know, but he is utterly inept to have charge of such a train as this -
Completed

half a minute then went away - The staff had to listen & Fury's chief clerk attempted to defend Fury's action by saying that if he discharged one teamster a hundred would leave -"Let them go at once" I said  "I will give you a hundred better teamsters in an hour"  The fact is Fury is entirely under control of these men - He
Completed

and it only makes enemies.  I have said more than enough to record my protest against such management & as it is of no avail I congratulate myself that the expedition is over & I most sincerely hope I will never go on another under Crook - As I have before said he is entirely deficient in organization & organization is necessary not only to success but to the health & comfort of the Troops -
Completed

Nor do I know any regular qrmr who is - I do know several Lieutenants of the Line who would run it perfectly.  Lawton Mackenzies Qrmr could do it well & Trout would have the whole thing run as smoothly as a sewing machine - I am utterly & thoroughly disgusted with the management of the Logistics of this campaign - There is no use saying anything
Completed

& comfortable after 50 below - Tonight 9.30 pm. the Ther is 12º above & I am lying on the outside of my bed writing this - quite comfortable in a temperature that would be considered very cold in the East - Took dinner with Mackenzie tonight my teams getting in after the dinner was over.  He came to my tent afterwards & spent a half hour -I was at his tent when my troops came in &
Completed

The March was a very trying one - When we started the mercury was frozen but it moderated very rapidly getting to about zero by 1 pm.  Getting through the pass of Pumpkin Butter was like going into another climate.  On the other side I was frozen up & bundled up - as soon as we passed I got off my Kuklux cap & was even too hot at that - Everything is comparative - zero is warm
Completed

Camp on Mini Pusa near mouth of Wind Creek Dec 26 1876
Reveille at 6.30 but late getting off again on account of the tardiness of teamsters  Genl C. sent me word early to follow his trail as he proposed to strike out a new road.  I did so. we had to cross a few bad ravines but the route was good.  Our course was almost directly south - varying a very little to the eastward & in about
Completed

though I took the pains to come out & instruct Townsend where to go.  he as usual botched everything & got his wagons tents & cook fires just with my Hdqrs. I'll locate him hereafter - Take it all in all it is a Xmas long to be remembered & I dont care ever to have another like it - Excellent camp - Wood & water plenty & good grass.  3 horses & 3 mules killed or abandoned today - Distance 20 miles
Completed

It is an immense bed? with plenty of timber but no running water.  However we found a few water holes.  The ice on them being a foot thick & cut a way into them with axes - The water is abominable full of alkaline impurities.  The water at Grand spring last night made me sick & this tonight caps the climax  I should mention as one of the minor discomforts of a campaign in this
Completed

10 miles we struck the regular beaten road (that from Fetterman to Reno & by which we came out)  It was like an old friend & all hailed it with satisfaction.  After about 16 miles we struck Wind Creek where we camped going north - There being no wood & the water being frozen solid, we came down Wind Ck nearly a mile to its junction with the middle fork of the south fork of Cheyenne
Completed

I have suffered all day but have gotten "kinder" used to it - Another of our common discomforts is the snow.  For more than a month we have been marching, unclear & sleeping in the snow until we have almost come to regard it as a natural covering of the earth - I have the loose snow scraped off the ground inside of my tent - but make no effort to have it cleared away this would require too
Completed

country that with the single exception of Willow Creek (where we camped on our night march after the Indians) we have not found a drop of palatable water.  It is all saturated with gypsum or other alkaline matter & is not only sweet & sickish to the taste, but acts violently on the bowels, bringing on griping pains & profuse foetid discharge.
Completed

which serve as rug & prevent the ground underneath from thawing & getting damp - Under my bed & table the snow is always intact when I leave the spot in the morning -  

  Another & great discomfort in so cold a country is the scarcity of fuel - We always go to wood if possible but many times we cant find it - Last night we were lucky enough to get an abundance & expecting none at Wind
Completed

much work.  In fact the whole tent floor would have to be dug up - no easy matter when the ground is frozen for a foot in depth.  We cant drive a tent pin.  a hole is first made in the frozen soil with a pick & the pin inserted  The snow just around the stove melts & becomes a mud puddle.  I have a couple of grain sacks beside my bed
Completed

time not expecting more than one wash of my hands in a day - So we are jolly dirty - but dont mind it a bit - It is really astonishing to see how comfortable pleasant & jovial men can be, living as we do -

 Yesterday while at dinner with Mackenzie he was remarking on the general success of our campaign & "we are now going back" said he "without any
Completed

Creek where we camped going out we brought some with us - By coming down Wind Creek to its junction with this branch (called Middle fork) we find a great abundance -

 Another minor trouble is the scarcity of water - Even when we camp at water holes the supply is frequently so limited that we cant wash our faces in the morning & I have for some
Completed

When he has to work with his nose & his fingers for three or four hours without intermission to prevent their freezing, he suffers & he suffers acutely.  It is nothing to boast of when a man has a good heart & accepts what fate sends him - but did he give up he would suffer permanently - One additional step would have made our suffering permanent for some of us - so while we
Completed

suffering at all" - "Well" I said "while I agree with you generally on the good effect of our winters work I can not agree that we have done it without suffering - We have not suffered permanent ill nor lost our lives or our limbs - but when a man lies in his bed under a weight of clothing actually uncomfortable & yet shakes & trembles with cold -
Completed

in this country, without great suffering - bodily torture - & if he has the pluck & manliness to go through it without complaint or murmur it is only a proof of those qualities & not that he is comfortable - Every man of this Com'y has suffered acutely yet one hears no complaint -

  Yesterday morning a man was striking a tent & without thinking picked up a number of iron tent pins
Completed

congratulate ourselves in getting through without permanent disability we can not say truly that we have done so without suffering".  "Well" he replied laughing, I mean we have not suffered like many other poor fellows under similar circumstances - Henry's command for instance"  No man or men can go through a winter campaign
Completed

in contact with the iron while eating -

 We found here waiting for us a train loaded with forage & all the animals have tonight a good Xmas supper -
  There was also a large mail for our Command.  I got a letter from Father & Mother dated  5th - all were a little scared - but jolly - Wishing the boy to distinguish himself but hoping he will get into no danger
Completed

carried them to the bag in which they were to be put & threw them down.  They took with them all the skin of the inside of his hand -

  Some of the feed troughs furnished by the Qrms Dept are of iron - All those I have noticed since this cold snap are covered with blood & pieces of flesh when the poor mules have got their lips or tongues
Completed

The world applauds the success, but conscience approves him who does his work to the best of his ability whether he be successful or not - Neither myself nor my Com'd  have done any thing brilliant but we have done our very best & had our luck put us in a fight we would have made a name for ourselves - or I am mightily mistaken.  That's all!
Completed

just such a contradictory letter as a dear old Dad & Man would wish to their only Boybaby - It did me a world of good & reconciled me somewhat to going home without any special glory - The world applauds success while success is an accident that may come to the stupid & unenergetic as well as to the brightest & hardest worker -
Completed

time & trouble in writing one letter than a hundred would cost me -
The weather today has been delightful.  Ther'r from 12º this am to 22º at 2 pm -  a lovely temperature & springlike after the experience of the last few days -

 Excellent camp - water bad & scarce but we are sheltered & have plenty of wood.  Distance 17 miles
Completed

The order for my Regt to go to Kansas is a fixed fact - Letter from Rice - Hdqrs left on 16th.  Thats good.  No letter from Julia - The poor little woman thinks she writes every week - Father & Mother write every week & I get letters regularly by every mail - I cant blame her for letter writing is her purgatory & she takes more
Completed

last to leave Camp - It was snowing hard & kept it up all day a regular Norther - Fortunately it struck us in rear & bad as was the day we did not suffer much as it was not extremely cold - The Ther' was however not far above zero.  One man had his nose badly frostbit -

 A rascally Doboy came near making a vacancy for some body for in shooting at a rabbit his ball
Completed

South fork [?Mini Pusa?]  Decr 27th 1876

 Had to make my own fire again this am  My man is wretchedly stupid but tries so hard that I have not the heart to get rid of him.
 The troops got off at 7.30  I remained behind to see my wagons packed - We were all late with our breakfast & my wagons were the very
Completed

little after      4 pm - After getting things started for a comfortable night I went over to see Genl Crook.  He leaves us tomorrow to go in to Fetterman - we take two days to make the distance

 I spoke to him about our going to Kansas that we had a long journey ahead & that it would be a favor if he would allow us to go on at once   He said he did not intend to issue orders breaking
Completed

which missed the rabbit of course passed apparently directly through my party & so near that my horse dodged & shook his head - It was a long tedious ride - The men [?halled?] along splendidly.  I soon overtook the column & came on ahead - I got to camp 2 pm the troops abt 3 & the wagons kept coming for an hour later - Everything was in by a
Completed

at Omaha Bks & that it takes a little time to pack up - However I dont doubt but I will get every thing all right - with or without his consent - 
A large paper mail with a few letter came today from somewhere - I got a letter from Laura - all is in good condition at home - as she says "every thing is getting on splendidly & the cow has a calf"
My tent full of visitors
Completed

up the expedition but would issue special orders relieving us from duty with it - I then asked him to order us all to Omaha to which he demurred & had various of the ways of doing a very simple thing - Wanted me to order the Captains & 1st Sergts of Co to Omaha to get all the property &c &c  He totally ignores the fact that all of us have houses fitted up
Completed

Sage Creek  1st crossing  December   28 76 -
Had to make my own fire again this am.  D--d my stryker a little for his stupidity when he commenced to whimper whereat my easy soul relented & felt bad - I am too good tempered - I feel it more & more every day - Everybody in contact with me takes advantage of it - My cook swindles & steals from me - my
Completed

until 10 pm.  Had a very pleasant evening - Campbell sent me the Army & Navy Journal which has a good notice of my book - which however is not out yet - or was not when the notice was written -

 It is not snowing at present & we may have a good day tomorrow  First rate camp - plenty of wood - water - grass scarce as Cavy camped here going up -

Distance 21 miles -
Completed

& if we attend to the little things as they occur we will generally have no occasion to attend to greater things - What with laziness & force of habit I dont attend to the little things & though I can moralize over my failure tonight I wont do any better tomorrow -  

 I stopped just here to put some wood in my stove & while doing so Dr Price came to my tent to tell me that the thermometer
Completed

tent pins are stolen - my fire is not made - yet I "bear the ills I have rather than fly to others I know not of" -  I begin to think I am getting too old or philosophical to do very well for myself - When little things go wrong I find myself constantly saying "is it worth the trouble of a row" & I generally decide in the negative - & this is wrong for it is the little things that make life
Completed

became much colder - It will probably be 25º below zero before morning.

  It is astonishing what low temperatures we get to endure without knowing it - At no time so far this winter have I had on all the trappings I have provided nor have I so far worn an under coat - nor felt the need of one - I have on a perfect bundle of clothing - two flannel
Completed

indicates 15º below zero & I am rather disposed to think that moralizing at that temperature & in a tent is rather an unusual thing

  It has been cold all day -  When we  started 7.45 am it was snowing a little - very fine icy pellets - It stopped that & kept getting colder - On the march the temperature was from 6º to 10º above but after sunset it
Completed

is tied a cashmere handkerchief.  On my hands are a pair of silk & a pair of woolen gloves (I have seal skin but they are very cold)  This is my day gear for very cold days & I have worn it all but a few times - Besides these I have a thick undercoat, a pair of [?S.....?] leggins & a water & air proof overcoat which I have not worn - I am now lying in bed
Completed

& 1 buckskin shirt, a vest, a cardigan & an overcoat - One pair of flannel & one pr buckskin drawers & a pair of soldier pants protect my legs  Two pairs woolen socks, a pair of soldiers boots & buffalo overshoes keep my feet warm   My head boasts a Ku Klux Cap with visor to cover my face, a thick padded woolen hood - over which
Completed

& think of sleeping in a tent without fire with the ther' 50º below zero - We have had it at least that - though we could not tell exactly how low the temperature was as Mercury freezes at 42º below.  On the night before Xmas we went to bed with the ther' -30 when we got up the mercury was frozen

 One of the officers thawed it out hung up the
Completed

covered with a couple of blankets but with arms &  shoulders exposed.  I have a stove & tolerable fire but it is almost incredible to think I can be so comfortable in a tent, with the temperature outside as low as it is - Weather that our eastern friends would think unbearable, we find very comfortable - Think of riding for seven hours with the Therº below zero
Completed

about 3 pm - The road is fairly good but the marching is bad - the snow & sand clogging & balling the feet - The com'd was pretty well played out when we got here.  but there was very little straggling - Townsend has no discretion about marching the men & rushed them at a great rate today
Completed

ther' & in two minutes it was again frozen - This was repeated & it took longer to thaw the mercury over the fire than it did to freeze it when the instrument was hung out -
There's weather -
Genl Crook left in this am & went with Fetterman
We came on quietly & slowly - The troops arrived at this camping place
Completed

We are now only 10 miles from Ft Fetterman & all hands are looking forward to it as the first glimpse of civilization - I would have camped further up the creek but that there was no water to be found   This camp is almost waterless, a little alkaline & discolored fluid having been discovered under 15 inches of ice - in the holes that we found passable
Completed

He was excited I suppose by the prospect of soon getting into Fetterman - Several complaints were made against him by the Officers but I took no notice of them  If I am to play Brig Genl I must trust my Battalion Comdr in such things - I will however take an opportunity to let him know I dont approve of such speed -
Completed

after our arrival & while waiting for the wagons, a young Lieut began descanting on pic-nics.  Their pleasures & discomforts - I spoke up very seriously "Why should there be anything in the color green to give it a preference over other colors - You eulogise green grass, green leaves & all things green - Is not the mantle that Mother Earth now wears as
Completed

water in when we passed here before - The country is miserable - almost a true desert - much broken & cut up - No wood. no water. scarce any grass - nothing to relieve the eye but a scanty growth of sage brush & all covered with a mantle of white - While I & my staff were lying around a sage brush fire on the snow
Completed

Fort Fetterman Decr 29, 1876
Reveille at 6.30 - Broke Camp 7.30 - The night was very cold so cold that I could not sleep & sometime before morning I got up & made a fire after which I had a very delightful nap - The sunrise was extraordinarily gorgeous - something I have never seen before
Completed

becoming to the eye - as soft to the touch - Why should picnics be identified only with verdancy ="  The stare of surprise of the youngster & the grin of appreciation of the oldsters was sufficient reward for my effort at moralizing - We brought wood - camp had no wood water nor grass    Distance 20 miles
Completed

what appeared a vast spout of flame - passing through all the colors & reaching to beyond 45º   To the right of the sun & some 20º away was a brilliant portion of a rainbow.   The gradation in color of the horizontal streaks of cloud & color gave an idea of immeasurable distance -  It seemed
Completed

very near the horizon to the east was a horizontal streak of light so brilliant as to be trying to the eyes - just above one less brilliant & another & another each less brilliant than the other until the colors melted at last into the cold gray of the zenith - From the sun which could not yet be seen.  Came up
Completed

was very cold - not so cold as our Xmas - but second only to it - The ther'm was at this pnt 29º below zero this morning at reveille & with us it got no lower for several hours

  I reached this post about 11 a.m. went up to see Gen'l Crook whom I found at Col
Completed

as if one was looking at a landscape of thousands of miles in extent from the very center of which arose the vast funnel or spout of flame - I have seen the Sun Dog but a few times in my life, but the one this morning was well worth early rising to see - The day
Completed

ready for transportation  Went to Sutters store & saw everybody - stayed until my wagons got in & though I was very careful to drink only a spoonful at a time, I found myself nearly tight when I came out into the cold air - There is nothing new beyond what we have had in our mail
Completed

Carlton's Qrs - paid him or rather them quite a long visit - I am to take the Arty & 25th Infy to the R.R. via fort Laramie  We start on the day after tomorro - I have authority to order Officers & Supts of 23d to go in advance of the Com'd to Omaha Bks & get all the property
Completed

of the dryest Cotton wood the tent is not heated.  One can keep warm by sitting over the stove but there is little real comfort in the tent - Another great discomfort is the lack of water for washing - not only our faces & hands but our clothing has to go without & I have on now a suit
Completed

No letters or anything for us here - It has moderated very much & with a good fire of pine wood in my tent I am more comfortable than I have been in a week.  Among the minor discomforts of which I spoke a few days ago, I should have mentioned poor wood, With a stove crammed full
Completed

My breath froze  on the cloth & that froze the bridge of my nose - met Mrs Carlton today  she is a sister of Pollock 9th Infy & daughter of the old bookseller of Harrisburg - I used to know her when she was a girl - before her marriage.  She is not pretty - never was. pettite & wears huge
Completed

of under clothing which I have had on for three weeks.

 I froze my nose slightly today but dont think it will hurt me any way. 
 My Ku Klux nose & mouth piece strikes across my nose leaving a slit for the eyes -- My frozen part was first when the top of this piece touched my nose
Completed

give me such a cold as would make me miserable all the rest of my journey - a very quiet evening everybody visiting at the post or having a jamboree -

 Distance today 10 miles - good road -  Have been marching constantly for 8 days
Completed

eyeglasses- she was rather frigid, which I dont yet know if mere manner or pique at my not calling on her before I left here - Dr Hoff invites me to stay at his house which I declined of course as  I have to march many miles yet & a night sleep in a house would probably
Completed

& do not take it for I am authorized to go on to Cheyenne by stage & direct to Omaha so as to have my things packed by the time the troops reach there

 Several other officers go with me - after getting through all my work I went up to the post to call on the Ladies - visited Mrs. Carlton  Mrs. Andrews, Bubb Hoff
Completed

Fort Fetterman Decr 30, 1876
Up late this morning - After breakfast sent the adjt up to Hdqrs for orders.  Got them by 10 am & all satisfactory - I take my com'd with me to Ft Laramie  There I break it up & leaving 9th & 14th take the Arty & 23d to Cheyenne
Completed

the post [?] [?Tailer?] paid the post Com'y bill - Came back to camp about 5 pm & remained there though invited to whist & cribbage parties   It is a very hospitable post & the Officers all live well - It has been wretched weather - not cold but snowed nearly all day - It is clear & lovely tonight but colder - Orders issued for early start tomorrow - Mackenzie left today
Completed

& Ferris - Dined with Andrews & had another invitation to Carlton's but too late - Had already accepted & have not the capacity to emulate Pollock - He yesterday rec'd two invitations one to dine at 3 another to dine at 5 - He accepted both & ate both dinners.  I told the story on him today    

 Paid Rockwell's com'y bill - also paid
Completed

road abominable - up & down the steepest kind of hills all the time - It is difficult to conceive of a more broken country - The Laramie range of Mountains is just on our right, the Platte river on our left - The waters in their headlong course of only a few miles have cut deep gorges & left
Completed

La Bouté Ck   
Decr 31, 1876
Wagons reported late & too few of them - so the main portion of my Comd did not get fairly started until 9 am.  While the Comp of 23d Infy which were short of wagons did not get off until about 10 am
Completed

& our camp tonight in the valley of La Bonté Ck is covered to the depth of at least 12 inches on a level & in many places the drifts are from 3 to 5 feet deep - It has however been a very good day - The wind was sharp but in our backs & toward the afternoon that died
Completed

high & broken back bones across which the road twists & turns in immeasurable windings - Besides this the winds have brought vast quantities of snow from the high places & deposited it in the valley & ravines - Many times today or wagons were to the hubs in snow
Completed

there in five days - the marching was very hard today but my men are so tough now that I can guarantee any amt of hard marching   It is only the mules I am afraid off [sic]  We have however plenty of forage & I hope will fit through without trouble or delay -  If possible I shall
Completed

out - Tonight is lovely not cold nor windy & a lovely moon - but indications at a distance of more snow before morning.  We will be lucky if we get through unclear a blockade - Genl Crook started this morning for Cheyenne by the cut off & expects to be
Completed

The last day of the Centennial year.  In view of all the election noise, of the hardships of a winter Campaign & of my verging on to my 50th year, I could moralize quite lively tonight but that I am sleepy & have given orders for a very early start tomorro - Morality is a good thing in Civilization, but worth nothing, means nothing, here
Completed

make Ft Laramie on the 3d Jany. - for I wish to take the staff on the a.m. of the 4th for Cheyenne 
Dined with Clark & Rochelle  Had a splendid dinner for Camp - Roast Turkey & other nice things - Did ample justice to it all - good camp - wood water & grass - Distance 20 ms
Completed

all that remains of what was once the great plain stretching away to the N & east from the foot of the Laramie Range of Mts
Up & down all day.  In many places the drifted snow was  up to the knees of the men & mules & in some few places still deeper - The men marched admirably under the most trying circumstances & got
Completed

Horseshoe Creek  Jany 1, 1877
Reveille at 5.30 broke camp at 6.40 a most excellent start for the New Year - The road is a terrible one - rising one or two thousand feet above the valley of La Bonté on to an immense ridge
Completed

a day before me & I have made in two days a distance that he made in 3 - so much for Infantry after it is well seasoned.

  Mackenzie himself has gone to Chicago & his Cavy is under Com'd of Capt Mauck
 I have had a hard day.  I never felt better than when I got up this am but when lighting my
Completed

to our camping place on Horseshoe Creek at 2.40 pm.  Making all things considered almost unprecedented  march - The wagons got along well also & all were in by 3.30 p.m.  to my great surprise I found encamped here MacKenzie's whole command   He started from Fetterman
Completed

with griping pains in my bowels & have had a severe dysentery all day & between that & the burned eye, I have cause to remember my 1st Jany 77.   That is better tonight but I am rather weak -  Have a nice Camp, wood water & grass as good as can be found out here - I signed up all the
Completed

pipe after breakfast a puff of wind blew some sparks into my face - one into m eye which raised a small blister on the eyeball - It has given me great pain all day & I could hardly see.  It is better tonight & I hope will be all right in the morning.

  About 10 PM I was taken
Completed

without our breath freezing to our beards in icicles - but this is the first day of such a marvel for several weeks - We must be getting south.

 It thawed considerably - when not in deep snow the men marched in mud.  Tonight is stormy - wind & occasional snow -

Distance 20 miles - ([?Called ?] anywhere from 18 to 22- )
Completed

records of my Com' at night - Made out the [Mess?] bill.  Wrote the order relieving officers from duty to go in ahead of the Com'd from Fort Laramie - Wrote also rough draft of Genl Order breaking up the Command.

 The day has been quite mild.  It is a real treat to go for a whole day
Completed

chance that today would be abominable - It cleared off lovely however & the day has been all that could be desired except that it was rather too warm for us in our winter trappings -  Though the country is even more broken & much more picturesque than that passed yesterday & the day before  the road is much better & we all came along Men & wagons without difficulty.
Completed

Warm springs   Jany 2nd 1877
Reveille 5.30. broke camp 6.30.  Every wagon & the rear guard were out of camp & well started on the road by 7 am & while the morning star was still bright in the East - Last night the weather was very threatening - & it was a good
Completed

[text obscured by fold in paper] & forms a brook which runs away to the river - The water of this spring is warm not hot - but more than tepid - too warm to be palatable for drinking until it has been allowed to cool -

 No sooner had they arrived in Camp than Townsend & Egan posted away to Fort Laramie - I should have gone too had a wife been waiting for me as for them
Completed

We were told in advance that it was a long march not less than 26 miles & I was very agreeably disappointed to reach the camping ground at 2 pm  The Troops arrived at 3.15 & the wagons were all in by 4.30 -

  It is a very pretty camp in a narrow valley enclosed in pine & cedar covered bluffs of 3 or 400 feet high
  From the base of one of these a large stony
Completed

Fort Laramie WY 
Jany 3d 77
Reveille at 6.30.  Broke camp at 7.30 everything being ahead of us.  Had a pleasant march over a fairly good road for 13 miles to this post where I arrived at 11 am - the command getting in an hour later -

 Called on the Com'd Offr Major Evans 3d Cavy
Completed

It has been a long march but all things considered one of the pleasantest of our long trip - Weather & scenery have combined to make it enjoyable - Got up my last orders to be published tomorro  Saw Fury in reference to trains to go down with Arty & 23d - Fixed all satisfactorily & Went to bed - 

 Distance 23 miles
Completed

suit - packed my trunk & valise - Gave Clark a list of the things he is to take care of for me. 

  Issued all my orders breaking up the Com'd & ordering some officers to Courts etc - getting through in time to go back to Evans' to dinner at dark   Remained with him an hour after dinner when Randall & I went to the
Completed

at once - Then went down & put the Com'd in Camp & returned to Evans for lunch to which I did most ample justice - After this I made arrangements for an ambulance tomorro to take me to Cheyenne & came back to my tent to pack up - got out all my Citizen clothing - one rather dilapidated
Completed

do not take him in ambulance with me but I take care of my own first - Besides all will get to Cheyenne in time to take the same train that I expect to get - 

 Telegram from Crook late at night directing the train & consequently the troops to remain here for one day to rest the mules - The Mules
Completed

Billiard room.  Played 2 games with Pollock coming out even.  bade good by to such officers as were present & went down again to Camp - I take Randall Pollock & Dodge with me in ambulance tomorrow the other detached officers go on stage next day - Campbell is grouty  & put out because I
Completed

Philips Ranchs 
Chugwater  
Jany 4 . 77
Ambulance reported late with a very poor team of broken down cavalry horses - However we got off before 8 am - The road was very bad, snow in drifts sometimes nearly
Completed

are doubtless satisfied but the humans are disgusted

 Cold nasty wind today but it always blows here.  Tonight is not so bad.  Last night in camp of this most disagreeable winter campaign.  Thank Heaven !!

Distance today 13 miles
Completed

dark - Had a good supper & excellent room & bed - It has been very cold & blustery today but we were covered with buffalo robes & quite comfortable -
Distance 45 miles.
Completed

to the Hubs - & the side hills slippery with ice - Arrived at Owen's Ranche (Chugwater Springs) about 1 pm & had dinner - After getting into the valley of the Chug the road was good & we balled along splendidly, considering our team & arrived at Philips just after
Completed
that we only arrived at Horse Creek about 2 pm where we nooned & lunched.  Then went on to Pole Ck arriving just before dark - Good supper, but rather poor sleeping accommodations   Distance 22 miles
Completed

Loop Pole Creek   

 Jany 5 . 77

Up early & got a good start, hoping to make Cheyenne today but the snow was so deep & the road so slippery & bad going up & down the numberless hills & our team so poor
Completed

Martial is in session - commenced today - & the town is full of officers   More Rank than I have seen together since the War - Pope . Crook . King . Gibbon .Sykes . [Thieck?] & lots of others too numerous to mention.  Pope told me to take my time about getting to my
[from another page?]  Distance 18 miles
Completed

Cheyenne

  Jany 6 . 77

Up early & got a good start - The road proving much better than we expected we got along well & by 11.30 were safely landed at the R.R. Hotel Cheyenne, The Reynolds             Court
Completed

a crowd.  Genl Crook is here looking fat & jolly as ever & the Genl himself was more cordial than he ever was to me before - Jeff Davis is on the Court & he & Crook spent the Evening in Pope's room - both very quiet - Randall & I have same room at Hotel but he did [?bother?] me
Distance 18 miles
Completed

new post which is to be Fort Riley - so I determined to stay over here a day & see all the folks - Pollock & Dodge took the cars as they have to stop at Sidney.  Had a delightful evening mostly spent in Pope's room where there was quite
Completed

my return)  except in the matter of managing Indians & Crook is the best teacher in that branch of knowledge I ever saw -  Took the cars at 2.30 pm.  got a stateroom for our quartette for Randal goes down with me & Pollock & Dodge are to join tonight at Sidney -
Completed

On cars   Jany 7 . 77
No Court today it being Sunday so I spent the morning "gassing" with the old fellows.  I find myself quite a hero & an authority (though I knew as much before I went on the expedition as I do on
Completed

I slept through it all half waking occasionally & wondering what the train stopped so often for

  I remember concluding that I must wake on the stopping of the cars at the different stations - like the Miller who wakes when his mill stops - I was surprised next am to find we had been delayed
Completed

Omaha Bks  
Jany 8. 1877
Arrived at Omaha late our train having last night run into a herd of cattle sleeping on the track mashing them up & throwing engine & some cars off the track -
Completed

at this bridge there was a twist & a jolt then a dead halt . I opened the door & jumped out to find all the mules gone.   The leaders had swerved at the bridge near the front of the ambulance diagonally against one of the posts of the railing - then came straight with a plunge broke the
Completed

for 7 hours in one spot

  An ambulance was waiting for us at Depot & getting in we started for the post.  Just outside the fence of the Garrison is a bridge over a small ravine.  It was very cold & we were all shut up in the ambulance & just as we arrived
Completed

at my own post. & at the very last moment of the expedition -
We walked to our houses.  I woke up Joe & Laura had a bed prepared for Randall & we were soon in the land of nod - Home again safe & sound & as I drew the clean sheets about me, I could not
Completed

tongue sharp off at the [?] & all went for the stable.  It was a narrow escape for us for if the tongue had not broken the post would & we would have been tumbled into the ravine.  so the greatest danger I encountered on my great winter expedition was
Completed

resist a sigh of relief & thankfulness -
And thus after 67 days of hardship & exposure I am again at home all right & comfortable.
Completed

Winter Campaign
1876
